summary: study population comprised all probable SARS patients whose cases were reported to the department of health on or before may 16, 2003 (n = 1,690) radiographic evidence of infiltrates consistent with pneumonia and current temperature >38°C or a history of such at any time in the preceding 2 days. the criteria for cases are equivalent to those in the world health organization’s case definition for probable SARS cases (7). the index case-patients were asked whether they were hospital workers, inpatients before contracting SARS, or residents of the Amoy Gardens. the rest of the index case-patients were classified into the known sources group. random telephone numbers were selected from up-to-date local telephone directories. at least three calls were made before an unanswered call was considered as a noncontact. a proxy, who was most familiar with the family situation, was interviewed. 727 cases-patients belonged in one of the four categories (61% of 1,192 cases) another 240 (20.1%) had come into contact with a SARS patient within a 10-day period before onset of fever. for 347 (29.1%) participants, the source was undefined. 212 cases of the undefined source group had visited at least one of the above-mentioned categories of places. patients were more likely than controls to have visited the amoy gardens. Frequency of visiting crowded places was, however, not significant in the univariate analysis. the absolute percentage is not high among the 1,192 case-patients. the number of community-acquired cases in less populated cities should be much lower than that of Hong Kong. this finding should be interpreted with care as >90% of the general public wore face masks in public places, and >85% avoided visits to public places during the epidemic. the study has a few limitations as well as strengths. approximately 72% of all SARS case-patients were included in the study. the study also has strength of matching for age, sex, and reference time. public health measures may have contributed to the control of SARS epidemic in Hong Kong.
